This crisis is the direct result of structural racism & years of policy violence in our health system. 

‚û°Ô∏è My Anti-Racism in Public Health Act would help dismantle the racist systems & practices that create the inequities that contribute to the Black maternal health crisis.

Additionally, to inform our work to confront this crisis, my colleagues and I are calling on @USGAO to investigate:

‚úÖBarriers to maternal health ed & maternal care
‚úÖImpact of maternal health crisis on incarcerated folks
‚úÖImpact of COVID-19 on our maternal health crisis

BIPOC patients are more likely to die in childbirth & more likely to contract and die from COVID-19. 

‚û°Ô∏è That's why I introduced the COVID-19 Safe Birthing Act to provide critical protections & care for pregnant people during the pandemic.

I've taken several steps this Congress to advance our fight for maternal health justice:

A safe pregnancy should be a fundamental right.

‚û°Ô∏è My Justice for Incarcerated Moms Act ensures pregnant people behind the wall have the resources and support they need to birth in dignity.

Our work on maternal health justice spans committees. Today @OversightDems held a hearing on Birthing While Black.

The maternal health crisis reaches far beyond the tragedy of maternal mortality. For every maternal death, there are nearly 100 instances of severe maternal morbidity, or "near-misses." 

We need to implement evidence-based solutions to prevent these dangerous situations.

Recently, the CDC released a report showing that the maternal mortality rate is rising.

More than two-thirds of the deaths are preventable. 

This is unacceptable, and the time for action is now.

Black women are three times more likely and Indigenous women are more than twice as likely to die from pregnancy-related causes as non-Hispanic white women. 

We must address these disparities to ensure that women of color can have a safe and healthy pregnancy and birth.
